definition: no end to learning (idiom); There's always something new to study./You live and learn.
to learn/to study/to imitate/science/-ology
not to have/no/none/not/to lack/un-/-less
to stop/to prohibit/until/only
border/place/condition/boundary/circumstances/territory

sentences.english: Therefore, our perspective future, knowledge is infinite, achievement foresight.
sentences.chinese: 於是，我們前瞻未來，學無止境，成就遠見。

sentences.english: Instead, be open-minded and realize that there will always be more for you to learn.
sentences.chinese: 相反，你應該保持開放心態並認識到學無止境。

sentences.english: Education never ceases, even after we leave school.
sentences.chinese: 學無止境，即使在我們結束學業後也是如此。

sentences.english: I like shoot and come here . Endless learning. I am a student forever.
sentences.chinese: 我喜歡攝影而來到這裏，學無止境，我永遠是學生。

sentences.english: Knowledge has no limits. I wish you to become the very best international basketball referee.
sentences.chinese: 學無止境，祝願您成爲最優秀的國際級籃球裁判員。

sentences.english: We have a long way to labor, because learning is endless.
sentences.chinese: 我們長路漫漫，只因學無止境。

sentences.english: "Live and learn" might be the hardest work out there.
sentences.chinese: “學無止境”是世界上最難做到的事情。

definition: study tirelessly (idiom, from Analects)
selfless/impartial
not feel ashamed to ask and learn from one's subordinates
superior judgment/sagacity
restrain yourself and return to the rites (idiom, from Analects); to subdue self and observe proprieties/(any number of possible translations)
sea of learning, no horizon (idiom); no limits to what one still has to learn/ars longa, vita brevis
lit. an old steed in the stable still aspires to gallop 1000 miles (idiom); fig. aged person with great aspirations
to review the old and know the new (idiom, from the Analects)/to recall the past to understand the future
when you teach someone, both teacher and student will benefit
vigorously pursuing knowledge, while scrupulously abiding by the rules of decorum (idiom)
subtle words with profound meaning (idiom)
On learning, classic book by Confucian philosopher Xun Zi 荀子 (c. 310-237 BC)
instructing with tireless zeal (idiom, from Analects)
to have a sense of shame
to be strict with oneself
to follow through/to carry through to the end
